It is good to be zealously affected always
in a good thing
Gal. 4:18.
Enthusiasm, then, is either good or bad
according to the character of its object.
Zeal for a good thing is good.  Zeal for
a bad thing is bad & The Bible sharply
discriminates between the true and the
false.  Paul condemns himself for that misdirected
impulse which drove him exceedingly
mad in persecuting the early Christians.
He condemns the Jews for having a zeal
of God, even, but not according to knowledge.
The apostle James rebukes a bitter
zeal as follows:  If ye have bitter envying
and strife in your hearts glory not
and lie not against the truth.  John said
come with me and see my zeal for the
Lord and then went forth and slew
Completed

the whole house of Ahab and the worshippers
of Baal.  That was a proud zeal.  Christ
accused the Pharisees and Scribes
of a partial zeal when He said -- "woe
unto you Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites
for ye pay tithes of mint, and anise
and cumin, and have omitted the 
weightier matters of the law, judgment,
mercy and faith."
While thus sharply distinguishing between
what is right and wrong. The Bible
would seem to encourage and require
the highest degree of enthusiasm in
so good a thing as the effort to build
up Christs Church on earth.--
Completed

It is still the "joiner of God unto salvation
to every one that underlinebelieves/underline."  Full faith is
as essential to him who proclaims it
as to him who receives it.  The gospel
becomes of none effect when we act as
if we half believed it.  The key to the 
successful proclamation of Christ -- is
underlineto be actuated by that spirit -- which
comforts with the truth we preach/underline
In this the example of the apostles is of importance to us, and I have thought to
call your attention to a theme which I 
may state thus: --
underlineEnthusiasm as related to religious
effort. /underline
In using the word "enthusiasm" it is
not to be understood as including an
element of fanaticism - but simply as
the word exponent of our emotional
nature when animated by the highest 
and holiest motives.
Completed

The inconsistency of the objection often
urged against an outward display 
of an earnest spirit is evident. It
admits of the impulse, but objects to its
activity. Such a nicer is family at warunclear nature and revelation.  God has given to us an emotional capacity or impulse, which moves us in attraction or revulsion whenever our object is presented, and corresponding to this he has offered up before us mays of service, and commands us to run for his honor, for the good of others, and for our own.  That impulse like a sliding scale, rises or lowers in exact accordance with the importance of the object presented.  It is the thermometer
Completed

which measures the heat or cold of the sense of individual responsibility. Any principle cherished that interferes with this is sin against nature and against God.
The Bible also recognises and commends enthusiasm both in the character of its appeals and in the style of its language. Its entreaties to men to repent are not addressed merely to the understanding, though that is the basis of responsibility, but to the affections and will. These three powers make up the mind. The understanding is the power of perceiving facts. The affections are that which feels in view of facts presented. The will is the power to act when would by the impulse of feeling. Now the Bible instructs and fills the mind with the facts of Salvation. That it may have a basis upon which not merely to make
Completed

us feel but to act. Christs great charge against men was not that they did not know and feel, but that knowing and feeling they would not act. "Ye will not come unto me that ye might have life." James says, To him that knoweth to do good + doeth it not, to him it is sin
All the invitations, and warnings, and promises of the Bible are of the most enthusiastic kind stirring nature. Listen to this: "Tho, every one that thirsteth come ye to the waters, yea, come buy wine and milk without money and without price." "Awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead and Christ shall give thee light." "Repent for the kingdom of heaven is at hand" "Be zealous therefore" "He that believeth shall be saved and he that believeth not shall be damned condemned" "Come unto me". "Whosoever will may come" "Woe unto him that are at ease in Zion." O Jerusalem, Jerusalem, thou that killest the prophets and stonest him that I sent unto thee, how oft would I have gathered thee
Completed

but ye would not." The strongest elements of the most perfect language ever spoken were combined to give expression to the impulse of God who was moved with compassion toward lost man.
At the same time the Bible sharply distinguishes between the true and the false. Paul condemns the Jews for having a blind zeal, a zeal of God, even, but not according to knowledge. That was fanaticism. No one has ever condemned such a spirit in stronger and more explicit terms than God himself. James rebukes a bitter zeal. "If ye have bitter envying and strife in your hearts glory not and lie not against the truth" John had a proud zeal, "Come with me and see my zeal for the Lord." said he and then went forth and slew the whole house of Ahab and the worshippers of Baal. Christ accused the Pharisees and Scribes of a partial zeal when he said, "Woe unto you scribes
Completed

Crawling or Running.
A person was lately complaining in my presence, says Mr. Jay, "Oh, sir! I do not like this railroad pace to heaven." "Why sir," said I, "it is the Scriptural pace. It is good to be always zealously affected in a good thing and you can never go to heaven in a hearse. Does not David say, 'Then will I'—crawl along? No. 'Then will I'—walk along? No. But, 'Then will I run in the way of thy commandments, when thou shalt enlarge my heart."
and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye pay tithes of mint, and anise, and cummin, and have omitted the weightier matters of the law, judgment, mercy and faith."
But very different from this is the earnestness which the Bible Commends. All true religious impulse finds its motive and guidance in the Word of God.
I Let us now consider, first, its necessity the necessity for such an impulse.
Nothing of importance has ever been done in the kingdom of this world or in that of Christ without well directed earnestness. I do not mean bluster, or pretention, or noise, but a persevering and animated spirit engaging the heart and mind and body alike in an activity corresponding with the importance of the object sought. Look back at old Nehemiah and the remnant of the Jews engaged upon the broken down walls of
Completed

A Call to Earnestness.
Hear what men said of Paul + Silas _
These that have turned the world upside down have come hither also.
Acts 17:6.
These apostles were enthusiasts. They believed in turning the world upside down, or viewed as a common result of their preaching, right side up. They were seized upon by the conviction that men were radically wrong, and that they were the divinely commissioned agents to set them right. Hence, "as they believed they spoke." The power of the Gospel had been positive on their own hearths, and so rebounded operated with equal force on the hearts of others. When they preached, it was not themselves but Christ Jesus the Lord, and the truth because the power of God unto salvation. It is said of
Completed

Paul that "when he reasoned Felix trembled" Tertullus called him a "pestilent fellow", and "a mover of sedition among the people", and Festus said, he was "mad" and "beside himself". But the true explanation of Pauls singular earnestness was not fanaticism, but simply, that he acted consistently with the import of what he believed. When therefore, Paul + Silas these two men, inflamed with zeal, went out together confirming the churches, and preaching in every synagogue the doctrine of Christ and Him Crucified, with all that such a truth involved, they did nothing more than what they ought to have done, and the result, when the Jews sought to put them to death saying, "These that have turned the world upside down have come hither also" was nothing more than what might have been expected. The same results may be confidently looked for today. The Gospel itself has lost none of its wonder working power. It is still the power of God unto Salvation to every one that believes
Completed

Look back at old Nehemiah and the remnant of the Jews engaged upon the broken down walls of Jerusalem, the sword in one hand and the trowel in the other. So weak were they, so small, and so reproached that as they gave themselves to such a mighty task it was no wonder that their enemies taunted them reproachfully as though they were dreamy fanatics. "What do these feeble Jews? That which they build, if a fox go up, he shall even break down their stone wall." But it is said "they strengthened their each others hands for this good work". and Nehemiah prayed, "Hear, O our God for we are despised: and turn their reproach upon their own head". and soon the gates which had been carried away were restored and the breaches in the walls were repaired, for it is further said, "the people had a mind to work."
Again, the temple of Solomon was to be built. How? Not by cool calculation alone; not by means of abundant wealth; but by the tact and zeal of earnest men and women. Their hearts and hands
Completed

their little gold and silver, their ornaments and their all was consecrated to that work. Their object was good, their motive was Gods Command, and their faith unwavering. So they were willing to be counted weak and small, they were satisfied to begin within their means, and keep within their means and bear without a murmur the reproach of the heathen. So they built the wall and their temple, and at the end had no Church debt and no Saddle for the devil to ride in. That was a consecration without which the temple would never have been built and the true worship never would not have been perpetuated. If the world is ever to be converted to God it will be by just such enthusiasm as this. Principle alone will never do it, however orthodox; nor mere moral rectitude; nor a cool
Completed

compliance with the commands of God, nor yet a spasmodic at gush of religiousness. None of these ever carried the Gospel to the heathen. It is not these that are now carrying forward the great work of evangelisation at at home and abroad. It is rather the pulsing of hearts inspired by the great fats of the Gospel that over leaping every difficulty preaches Christ to the perishing and saves men. 
The necessity for a serious earnestness is also seen in the fact that as the Gospel is claimed to be of so great importance to the happiness of men, unless there is a corresponding earnestness on the part of those who advocate it, men will not believe it. The contrast is too great. Men want tangible evidence of these things, and the most natural place to look for these things this is to the effect which the Gospel produces on the hearts of its adherents. They want to know how it works. They want to see samples of the goods they are asked to buy without money + without price. An inconsistency here is to them proof positive against all its the claims of the Gospel.
Completed

This is both natural and Biblical. Natural, because it bears the relation of Cause and Effect. These cannot be separated in thought. A genuine cause must produce a corresponding effect. It is Biblical because God has said "Ye shall know them by their fruits." This is the practical list which God gives to the world the liberty to judge of true and false Christianity. It would be well for us to consider that the world, so called, does not always make mistakes in its judgements. That it reasons from premise to conclusion as correctly as the Christians. And when it charges us most frequently of all with a failure to substanciate the claims of the Bible by lives corresponding to the pretended effects which the Gospel claims to produce, it is time for us either to wake up to the necessity of remedying the Evil, or to acknowledge
Completed

that the whole system is a sublime failure. One has well said, men cannot but feel that if religion is worth anything it is worth everything; that if it calls for any measure of zeal and warmth it will justify the utmost degrees of will. They may dislike, detest, scoff at and persecute those who exercise it, yet their consciences are all the while reminding them that, if there be a God, and a savior, a heaven and a hell anything short of such a life and love is hypocrisy, dishonesty, perjury! The Biographer of Baxter in Comparing him with Orton said, That Baxter would have set the world on fire while Orton was lighting a match. That was the secret of his success. Men were constantly crying out for mercy who came within his influence. The overwhelming power of infidelity in the present day is evidently owing not to the want of a sound fault on
Completed

the part of Christians, nor to gross forms of ungodliness which have overtaken some, but to the coldness of those who have the reputation for of orthodoxy and morality. The inconsistencies of the Jesuits made Italy a land of infidels. The question of today is "How much of modern infidelity may be traced to the indolence, the coldness and cold orthodoxy of protestantism?"
It is also evident that men cannot be reached always by reason and argument. Few men were ever brought into the kingdom of X by force of logic. They must be touched, awakened, alarmed The birth cry of every redeemed soul is sirs?, what must I do to be saved? or God have mercy upon me a sinner. But such results are produced only by the influence of earnest hearts on fire.
When the man of God went up into the
Completed

chamber on the invitation of the Shunamite mother to visit and restore to life her dead boy, he stretched his body upon the cold form and filled it with his own warm breath, and soon the boy lived again. So the hearts of men are dead, they must be touched by the warmth of the Gospel breathed out in the zeal and devotion of living men. Uncle John A story is told of Uncle John Vassar, nephew of the founder of Vassar College, which illustrates this point. During the war of the rebellion he was taken prisoner. Scarcely had he been confined, when upon meeting the general, he forgot that he was a prisoner of war, and laying both hands upon his shoulders said, "Say, General do you love Jesus? astonished and confounded the General thought he must have mistaken his meaning and inquired what he meant to which Uncle John replied "I mean, General, do you love Jesus? The General was so impressed with the simple earnestness
Completed

(There are low motives and high motives, all of which may be good 16 as far as they go and are to be encouraged in those who are actuated thereby The lower grade of motives are better than none at all. We should not depreciate a just gesture because it is not distinctively a Christians motive.
of this man that he ordered his men to let this man go where he pleased in the camp.
II The second thought is the motive power of this enthusiasm. (See above)
Yet The great aim of the Christian life is the salvation of a lost world. and What motive is adequate to produce the required such a result? There is but one and there can be but one. That is Christ. Others motives will reach men, and do but will them good even though they do not men? them to God. Other motives will help to build us a professedly religious society. and strengthen the morals of a Community for morality's sake, which is commendable. And yet the Christ motive is the essential thing. [[Which men dare to call a Church. Amusements will draw [the] a crowd. Sabbath day lectures on the fine arts, or on some distinguished character in history, or a parade of fashion, or even a tirade against Jesus X as the God-man and Savior are motives which move men, but none of these will build a hope on that foundation]]
Completed

other than which no man can lay which is Jesus Christ.
The Christian's motive This begins with the doctrine of a personal God and eternal God with all his perfections of Character. He We Chn believes that God created us, preserves us, and loves us; that he is immutable as to change, omnipotent as to power, omniscient as to his knowledge of us, holy as regards character and and just in all his dealing with men, and requires of us constant obedience and love.
He believes in the sinfulness and total depravity of man, that he does not love God nor obey him, that his carnal heart is enmity against God, is not subject to the law of God neither indeed can be.
That the soul is immortal and must live forever in heaven or hell happiness or unhappiness, according to the impartial and just decision of God the judge. That regeneration of heart is absolutely essential to life with God and to the enjoyments of eternity
Completed

18
according to the teaching of X "Ye must be born again". Holiness without which no man shall see God." "The pure in heart shall see God." That Jesus X the divine son of God, in order to save man from the wrath of God which was abiding on him, gave himself unto death in an atonement for his sins making it possible for God to be just and the justifier of every one who believeth in Jesus. That this atonement was perfect in every part and satisfied the claims of God upon the sinner so soon as he simply believes on Christ. So that he can say 
Nothing, either great or small 
Remains for me to do 
Jesus died and paid it all
Yes, all the debt I owe
That now nothing remains for the sinner to do but to accept of the work done
Completed

by X which like a golden remedy is unclear out to him in every invitation entreaty, promise and warning in the Gospel. That the rejection of Christ's proffers of salvation is the most cruel, inexcusable and terrible sin that can be committed. That the consequences of such rejection can be nothing less than an agravated condemnation the impossibility of pardon, and the eternal ruin of the soul. "He that believeth shall be saved but he that believeth not shall be damned". He that despised Moses law died without mercy under two or three witnesses: Of how much unclear punishment suppose ye shall he be thought worthy who hath trodden under foot the son of God, and hath counted the blood of the covenant an unholy thing, and hath done despite to unto the spirit of grace
Completed

20
Think now of the opposite of such fearful rejection all this sin, the blessings of accepting X. Hear Paul say, There is therefore now no condemnation to them that are in Christ Jesus, who walk not after the flesh but after the spirit. The wrath of God is all passed away and the sinner exultingly cries.
To God sin reconciled
His pardoning voice I hear
He owns me for his child
I will no longer fear
With filial trust I now draw nigh
And father Abba father cry.
The sting of death is extracted. The strength of sin, which was is the law is broken, and the believer joins in the song of the redeemed. Thanks be unto God who giveth us the victory through our Lord Jesus X.
Now, add to all this the thought that God has made the believer his agent for preventing the sinners ruin, and
Completed

responsible for his enjoyment of the blessings of redemption, together with the thought of the shortness of and uncertainty of life in which he has to do this work, and you will have some idea of the motives held out in the Gospel for the earnestness and consecration of X's disciples.
"Where we think of this vast array of motives with many other gathering about them, how it it possible for us to speak of life and death with so much of indifference? How can we speak of heaven and hell in such a careless, sleepy manner? Is it possible that we believe what we say? Are we in earnest or in a jest? How can we tell the people that sin is such a terrible thing, and that so much misery is upon them and before them, and be no more affected by it ourselves?
Completed

22
In a little volume called "Gods terrible voice in the City" describing the ravages of the great plague and fire in London, it speaks of the faithful Christian men and women who remained amid the danger to administer the consolations of the Gospel to the dying inhabitants "who hung with breathless eagerness upon their lips, to drink in Salvation ere the dreaded pestilence had swept them away to the limb. The Churches were crowded. But the pulpits were silent, for the unclear were fled. Then did those faithful men not preachers, but lay men. Stand up and proclaim X as the only hope of the sinner. The week day and Sabbath were all the same. Night and day their voices were heard. Graves were lying open around them; life seemed not merely a hand breadth but a hair breadth; death seemed nearer than ever. Every opportunity was improved. Oh, how they preached!
Completed

No polished periods, no learned arguments, no labored paragraphs chilled their appeals. No fear of man, no love of applause, no over scrupulous dread of strong expressions, no fear of excitement or enthusiasm prevented them from pouring forth the whole fervor of their hearts with unutterable tenderness over dying souls." Now you think of this and readily say, "Why at such a time as that I could preach like those men, as a dying man to dying men." You would not stop at such a time to think of your grammar or your eloquence, you talents or your standing in society. The trivial excuses which keep us from duty now would never crowd into our hearts. We would lift up our voices like a trumpet. Look to Jesus! Look to Jesus! for "He that believeth shall be saved."
Completed

24
But the great question with us is, Should it ever be other wise? Are not the motives to save men the same to day that they were then? Lacking only the intensity of local circumstances? Souls today are no less precious, and in no less danger. God is no less loving, and Jesus is no less "the mighty to Save".
III That discretion should be used there is no question. To be instant in Season, out of season is the rule of Christian conduct. But within the rule he is priveleged and urged forward to the utmost degree of earnestness. Whether at home or abroad, on land or at sea, in prayer or in praise, in business or in recreation, the same earnest spirit shrug? prevail. Ungodly men, even, love to see such a spirit exercised by Gods people. None are more severe in Criticism upon lifeless Christians and Churches than are they, and in their benevolence they will favor, if any, the hard working
Completed

churches. __ The general moral power of an active zeal is of more value to the Church of God than we sometimes think. Death wherever you find it is repulsive Life is attractive. Nobody goes to the charnel house unless he is obliged to. So spiritual death in a Christian heart Church is repulsive. The masses will not crowd that charnel house unless they are compelled. A soul out of X and feeling his need of Salvation will not go without trying him? to a reputed cold hearted Christian for advice no matter how cultured or of good repute in Society. That is a time when we seek those whom we know to be in close contact with Christ. The true theory is, we can not bring a soul any nearer to Christ than we are ourselves. Spiritual life, warmth, zeal is attractive. The crowd will go to such a place, no matter how plain the preaching
Completed

26
or how poor the pews. "A man may be free from all scandal either in Creed or conduct and yet may be a most grievous obstruction in the way of all spiritual good to his brethren or to the world. He may be a dry or empty cistern notwithstanding his orthodoxy. He may be freesing or blasting life at the very time that he is speaking of the way of life. He may be repelling men from the Cross even when he is in words proclaiming it. Such is what a mere profession does when there is no corresponding emotion of heart.
Now let us make this subject practical to ourselves. What do we need most? Certainly not a Sounder Creed, for we make our boast of a pure faith. Is it not to be actuated more by the motives drawn from the Gospel, and less by worldly expediency. Does God, a divine savior, a heaven, a hell, ruined souls but souls of infinite worth move us? Do we feel our responsibility for them?
Completed

27
Does the love of Christ constrain us? Do souls unsaved move us to pity? Do the voices of young converts saying "Come and hear all ye that fear the Lord and I will declare unto you what he hath done for my soul" awaken in our hearts unbounded joy? Ah, my brethren and friends whatever excuse we may have to bring it cannot stand the test of these questions. Where are we to day? What are our inner life experiences? What our secret joy. Let us honestly ask and answer these questions today and then go back to the cross of Jesus and get a new enthusiasm and bring it to the work of Saving a lost world.
Completed

The question is what was that act described by the word baptism which X commanded and which His apostles practiced. 2
How may we know what this act was?
I By ascertaining the meaning of the word. "Has it a plain, definite and certain meaning or is it vague, obscure and doubtful. The presumption is in favor of its having a precise and easily ascertained meaning It is exceedingly improbable to say the least that in instituting an ordinance of perpetual and universal obligation, our Lord should select to denote that ordinance a word the meaning of which was either obscure or indefinite. In a positive institution of this kind it is not enough that we observe the Spirit of the injunction. (Dif bet moral + p??tin precepts) words differ, some only express results as to Cleanse, to purify, others express acts of so general a Char, that they may be performed in several dif. ways, as to go to move, still others, specific, as to walk-run  dip-plunge. Such a word X used.
